title-group.article-title: A contextualised protein language model reveals the functional syntax of bacterial evolution

abstract.p: Bacteria have evolved a vast diversity of functions and behaviours which are currently incompletely understood and poorly predicted from DNA sequence alone. To understand the syntax of bacterial evolution and discover genome-to-phenotype relationships, we curated over 1.3 million genomes spanning bacterial phylogenetic space, representing each as an ordered sequence of proteins which collectively were used to train a transformer-based, contextualised protein language model, Bacformer. By pretraining the model to learn genome-wide evolutionary patterns, Bacformer captures the compositional and positional relationships of proteins and can accurately: predict protein-protein interactions, operon structure (which we validated experimentally), and protein function; infer phenotypic traits and identify likely causal genes; and design template synthethic genomes with desired properties. Thus, Bacformer represents a new foundation model for bacterial genomics that provide biological insights and a framework for prediction, inference, and generative tasks.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Bacteria are arguably the most successful organisms on Earth, having evolved over millions of years to inhabit diverse geographically environments [1], biological niches [2, 3] and ecosystems [4]; acquiring a vast metabolic repertoire to exploit diverse substrates to generate energy and create biomass [5], and developing complex behavioural traits such as virulence [6], immune evasion [7], and antibiotic resistance [8].

Bacterial genomes are known to encode these adaptations in a highly structured manner. For example: functionally related genes are usually found contiguously in operons [9]; transcription factors mostly regulate proximal rather than distant genes [10, 11]; and the genomic distance from the origin of replication generally predicts gene identity [12, 13]. Thus, the architecture of genomes may provide a framework to create informative representations of bacteria that could be used to understand the basis of evolution and enable generalisable functional predictions across taxa.

While previous large-scale analyses of bacterial genomes have been focused on specific applications (such as biosynthetic gene cluster discovery [14, 15] or predicting antimicrobial resistance [16, 17, 18]), and have been hampered by biases in public genome collections towards a few pathogenic bacteria [19, 20], we sought to develop a foundation model of bacteria that captures genomic structure and function across the full spectrum of bacterial diversity. To do this, we leveraged and curated existing diverse collections of metagenome-assembled genomes (MAGs) of bacteria [21, 22] derived from environmental sequencing across diverse habitats totalling over 1.3M MAGs and encoding almost 3 billion proteins, to create a scalable and data-driven foundation model of bacterial life.

We represent individual bacterial genomes as ordered sequences of proteins and use these as inputs to train a transformer-based, contextualised protein language model (pLM), called Bacformer (combining ‘bacteria’ and ‘transformer’), which learns the functional organisation of bacterial genomes. By pretraining the model to learn genome-wide evolutionary patterns, Bacformer captures the compositional and positional relationships of proteins and excels at fundamental functional genomic tasks - including predicting protein-protein interactions operon identification (which we validated experimentally), determining gene essentiality, predicting protein function, and accurately inferring phenotypic traits - as well as generative modelling, designing template synthethic genomes with desired properties.

sec.title: Training a genome-contextualised protein language model
sec.p: To develop a foundation model that captures evolutionary processes across bacteria, we first curated a broad taxonomic corpus of over 1.3 million metagenome-assembled genomes (MAGs) from over 25,000 species, spanning almost 1,500 orders and more than 70 biomes (Fig. 1A).

Every individual assembled genome was then modelled as an ordered sequence of proteins, each of which is represented using existing (ESM-2 [23]) protein language model (pLM) embeddings which capture evolutionary and functional properties of proteins [26, 23, 27], supplemented with rotary positional embeddings [24] and special tokens marking contigs; an arrangement that preserves the genomic ordering of proteins (Fig. 1B; see Supplementary Methods). Bacformer then utilises these enhanced embeddings of the entire proteome of an organism as inputs to a 12-layer transformer model [28], treating each protein sequence as a single token and processing the complete genome in a single pass.

Unlike DNA or protein-based language models that rely on pre-defined and constrained token dictionaries [29, 30, 31, 23, 26], Bacfomer accommodates the vast diversity of possible proteins by clustering them within embedding space into protein families, and using these labels as a discrete vocabulary for the autoregressive pretraining task, where the model learns to predict the family of masked proteins based on the context of other proteins in the genome (Fig. 1B). To ensure that our protein family clusters reflect genuine evolutionary relationships, we benchmarked them against established orthology databases (eggNOG [32]) and clustering methods (MMseqs2 [33]), obtaining normalised mutual information (NMI) scores of 74% and 88% respectively.

We observed that the pretraining accuracy and perplexity of Bacformer increased progressively during pretraining, improving with model and dataset size (demonstrating robust scaling laws seen with other transformer architectures [34, 35]), and generalised across species, to previously unseen genera, and across a range of genome completeness (Fig. S1; Fig. S2). We further refined Bacformer by extending pretraining to include 48, 932 complete genomes [36] (which we expect to provide important additional contextual information). Having access to complete genome boosted both zero-shot and finetuned performance, highlighting the value of an uninterrupted genomic context for the model (Fig. S2).

sec.title: Genome embeddings uncover evolutionary relationships across bacteria
sec.p: We next explored how the unified representation of bacterial genomes learned by Bacformer might provide insights into strain-level diversity and reveal sub-populations with distinct functional or evolutionary characteristics.

Existing clustering methods for bacteria operate only on closely related strains or rely on a limited set of marker genes and fail to consider gene content [37, 38, 39, 40, 41]. In contrast, Bacformer represents individual genomes across species in a shared embedding space (by averaging their contextual protein embeddings across the genome), enabling more robust strain-level comparisons based on the organisation of proteins within each isolate, and learning evolutionary relationships in an unsupervised way.

When applied to different sets of species, genera, and families (see Supplementary Methods), Bacformer accurately clustered strains (based on Adjusted Rand Index (ARI), Adjusted Silhouette Width (ASW), and NMI), considerably outperforming non-contextual ESM-2 embeddings by between 5 and 13% on ARI (Fig. 1C; Fig. S3). Moreover, even in this fully unsupervised manner, Bacformer preserved phylogenetic relationships. For example, for the Bacteroidales order, Bacformer embeddings produced average cosine similarities among species belonging to the same genus or to the same family of 0.96 ± 0.02 and 0.93 ± 0.05, respectively (Fig. 1D).

To evaluate whether Bacformer can resolve fine-scale diversity within a single species and identify meaningful evolutionary differences, we examined the Escherichia coli sample collection from the MGnify dataset [21]. We extracted Bacformer embeddings for each MAG and applied Leiden clustering [25], which clearly identified six distinct subpopulations (Fig. 1E) that were not well delineated when we used ESM-2 embeddings (Fig. S3), and were not driven by artifacts, such as genome sample or study origin (Fig. S4). Using pre-computed graphical pangenome analysis (Panaroo [42]), we identified several core and accessory genes that were significantly cluster-specific (adjusted p < 0.05, Fisher’s exact test) including: cbtA (in Cluster 2) that regulates cell division and elongation [43], stxA (in Cluster 5) that produces Shiga toxin responsible for life-threatening complications [44, 45], and fldP (in Cluster 3) that shields cells from oxidative stress and aids survival in low-oxygen environments [46, 47].

Bacformer embeddings can also be used to rapidly search for related genomes and infer evolutionary context, ecological niche and bacterial behaviours. We linked the 1.3M Bacformer genome embeddings to associated biological and clinical metadata to allow users to input an unannotated genome and retrieve similar genomes and associated phenotypes from our database. We validated the effectiveness of this method by applying a k-nearest neighbour (kNN) classifier to a held-out subset of bacterial genomes, demonstrating highly accurate retrieval across taxonomic ranks (Fig. 1F), with the method achieving almost 95% balanced accuracy across diverse genera.

Thus, Bacformer’s learned representations of complete contextualised genomes can reveal important evolutionary signals at both broad phylogenetic and localised strain-specific scales, and can be used to infer bacterial properties of unseen genomes.

sec.title: Bacformer reveals functional organisation of proteins
sec.p: Since Bacformer was trained to predict proteins from their genomic context, we anticipated that it would learn the evolutionary relationships between proteins and hence their organisation into functional networks.

To explore this potential emergent property, we first examined the model attention weights across thousands of genes in diverse genomes and found that Bacformer focuses on neighbouring genes (Fig. S5). While early layers distribute attention evenly, middle layers concentrate attention strongly on closest neighbouring genes, whereas later layers spread attention further along the chromosome (Fig. S5). Bacformer strongly updates embeddings of adjacent proteins (assessed by their cosine similarity), highlighting the importance of rotary positional embeddings in capturing gene order (Fig. S5), and indicating that it has learnt evolutionarily-conserved arrangements of contiguous proteins.

We therefore tested whether Bacformer could predict the presence of operons (physically adjacent co-transcribed genes that represent the fundamental regulatory units of bacterial genomics [9]). Using Operon DB [48] as ground truth, Bacformer accurately predicted operons across a wide range of gene sizes, markedly out-performing non-contextual methods, such as ESM-2 (Fig. 2A & B; Fig. S6).

Since current operon annotations are incomplete and potentially inaccurate, we performed long-read RNA sequencing of strains from five bacterial species (Mycobacterium tuberculosis, Mycobacterium abscessus, Staphylococcus aureus, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli), and obtained accurate zero-shot Bacformer predictions (AUC 0.76 − 0.92) when evaluated against experimentally validated operons (Fig. S2; Fig. S6).

We next evaluated whether Bacformer also implicitly learns genome-wide protein-protein interactions and hence would be able to predict functional protein networks. We computed pairwise cosine similarities in protein embeddings for a diverse test set of 2, 088 bacterial genomes across 1, 573 species and employed these in a zero-shot classification task, using different types of interaction score (combined, co-occurrence, neighbourhood, co-expression) from the STRING database [49] as binary labels. Bacformer considerably outperformed non-contextual protein language models (ESM-2) across all tasks (Fig. 2D) and was further significantly improved by fine-tuning (p-value < 0.01, t-test; see Supplementary Methods, Fig. 2E & F; Fig. S6).

When applied to P. aeruginosa (PAO1), the finetuned model uncovered previously known, as well as novel, high-confidence protein-protein interactions (Fig. 2G). We then used AlphaFold3 [50] to validate the novel interactions by predicting the structure of protein complexes (Fig. 2H). Protein complexes predicted by Bacformer had significantly higher ipTM scores (a metric that evaluates the accuracy of predicted protein-protein interfaces [51]) than for complexes based on random pairs (p < 0.003; Welch’s t-test; Supp Fig. S9), indicating direct physical binding.

Bacformer was also able to identify broader regulatory networks using its embedding similarity matrix, even without direct input of transcriptional information. For example, in P. aeruginosa, Bacformer was able to predict clusters of co-expressed genes more accurately than ESM-2 (Fig. S10) and identify networks mediating canonical quorum-sensing [52], biofilm formation [53], and motility [54] (Fig. 2I; Fig. S10), showcasing how Bacformer embeddings can reveal co-evolved, co-regulated, and interacting protein families.

sec.title: Predicting protein essentiality and functions
sec.p: To explore how kingdom-wide evolutionary signals and their genome-wide context learnt by Bacformer might reveal protein characteristics, we first examined its ability to predict protein essentiality (Fig. 3A). To create a ground truth dataset, we compiled genomes from 51 bacterial genomes across 37 species (from the DEG database [55]), providing a total of 169, 408 genes labelled as essential or non-essential. We then examined the performance of both zero-shot prediction and after fine-tuning; the latter significantly outperforming finetuned protein language (ESM-2) and DNA language (Evo [31]) models (Fig. 3B-C; Fig. S11). The finetuned Bacformer model was able to clearly separate essential from non-essential genes based on predicted probability distributions, achieving 0.81 ± 0.07 median AUROC across diverse genomes, and was able to identify many genes not previously annotated as essential which we scored as false positives, but which had orthologs in other species that are known to be essential, such as ribosomal proteins [56, 57] and tRNA synthetases [58, 59], indicating that our model made biologically plausible predictions.

We then evaluated the ability of Bacformer to predict protein function. To mimic the real-world setting where labels are often scarce, we used a limited set of 188 KEGG function labels [60] for 210, 975 proteins from 666 genomes (from the MGnify dataset [21]) for training, with a much larger held-out test set of 503, 295 proteins from 1, 931 genomes used for evaluation. Bacformer was able to significantly outperform ESM-2 and a kNN baseline model after training on the full dataset (Fig. 3D) and within low-data (few-shot) regimes (Fig. S9). Examining the protein embeddings of held-out genomes, Bacformer generated more cohesive groupings of proteins sharing the same function than ESM-2 (ASW scores of 0.71 and −0.05 respectively; Fig. 3E). Surprisingly, Bacformer was still able to make confident predictions even when the query protein itself was masked (0.56 balanced accuracy across held-out genomes; Fig. S10), indicating how important the learned contextual information is to model performance.

sec.title: Predicting bacterial phenotypes from genomes
sec.p: We next assessed whether Bacformer, having learned the structure of protein co-organisation and co-evolution, could be used to predict bacterial phenotypes. We found that Bacformer genome embeddings intrinsically reflect phenotypic traits even without fine-tuning. For example, isolate embeddings clustered by gram stain (Fig. S11) and by host environment, even when comparing closely-related species (for example within the Bifidobacterium genus; Fig. 4A).

Encouraged by these observations, we compiled a dataset of 24, 462 genomes from 15, 477 species that had been annotated with 139 distinct phenotypic traits [61, 62, 63] and used this to train separate classifiers for each phenotype, using Bacformer genome-level embeddings (Fig. 4B). Bacformer outperformed all benchmarks and accurately predicted phenotypes across a range of diverse traits including carbon source utilisation, optimal growth temperature, motility, and toxin production (Fig. 4C).

We then employed those phenotype-specific models with high predictive performance (balanced accuracy > 85%) to annotate the entire 1.3M genomes within the MAG corpus across 32 diverse phenotypes spanning metabolic, ecological, and physiological characteristics (Fig.4D; see Supplementary Methods). We provide these models, annotations, and accompanying metadata, which represent the first large-scale resource for kingdom-wide phenotype inference of bacteria for researchers to explore, filter, or extend for their own studies.

The accuracy of Bacformer in predicting phenotypes motivated us to further leverage its contextual genomic representations to discover the genes that are likely causally associated with specific traits by employing a gradient-based attribution method [64] that assigns importance scores to genes within a finetuned phenotype classifier.

We first examined the ability of this method to identify genes that were identified as related to sporulation, motility, and anaerobic growth (three phenotypes with some pre-existing ground truth knowledge of responsible genes [65, 66, 67, 60]), and found that phenotype-associated genes were assigned higher importance scores than other genes (Mann-Whitney test, p <10−10; Fig. S11).

We then examined in detail the sporulation-associated genes identified by Bacformer and found that: the canonical sporulation genes, spolllAG and spolllAF [68, 69], had been ascribed the highest importance scores; and that clustering the top 100 sporulation-associated genes revealed functionally distinct groups including known regulatory factors (sigG, spollAB [70, 71]) and structural genes (spoVE, spoVB [72, 73]), as well as previously uncharacterised, but plausible, candidates, such as katB, galE, and timB (Fig. 4F).

We next tested whether we could use Bacformer to identify niche-specific genes. Within Lactobacillus johnsonii, a gut bacteria found in several animal species [74, 75], Bacformer was able to identify known genes involved in host-specific adaptation, such as lacA and lacR (human, [74]), cas9 genes in livestock [76, 77], type III RM gene (mmr) (pig [76]), and banIM (chicken, [78]), as well as a credible set of additional novel genes (Fig. 4F). Finally, applying a similar approach to the Prevotella, a genus for which gene annotations and experimental validations are sparse, Bacformer was able to identify novel protein families specifically associated with gastrointestinal environments in different animal species (Fig. 4G).

Thus, by combining large-scale phenotype prediction with high-resolution gene-level attribution, Bacformer can not only assign specific traits across bacteria but can also discover potential causally-associated genes.

sec.title: Generating bacterial genomes de novo
sec.p: Since Bacformer has learnt genomic representations of bacteria that encompass evolutionary relationships, reflect protein functional organisation, and allow phenotype inference, we next looked to evaluate its potential for synthesising bacterial genomes de novo.

We first evaluated Bacformer’s generative capabilities by analysing its performance on unseen genomes. Bacformer achieved low perplexity (a measure of uncertainty when predicting the next token) across diverse genomes (Fig. 5A; Fig. S12), suggesting it captures the genomic architecture also of strains not encountered in the training set. We then prompted Bacformer with a short sequence of initial proteins from Escherichia coli and Staphylococcus aureus, and asked it to generate a complete genome (see Supplementary Methods). We showed that the resulting ordered sequence of protein families within synthesised genomes was comparable in distribution and ontological diversity to those of true genomes (Fig. 5A & B; Fig. S12), demonstrating Bacformer’s capacity to create genomes that span the full spectrum of protein functions. To ensure that the model did not simply recapitulate genomes seen during training, we generated multiple genomes from identical protein prompts while varying the temperature (a scaling factor in autoregressive sampling that controls randomness) and observed that Bacformer generated a variety of distinct genomes, none of which were replicas of any within the training corpus (Fig. S12).

We then tested whether Bacformer could accurately retrieve the full genome from an incomplete set of proteins, a valuable capability particularly for partial genomes typically recovered from metagenomic sequencing approaches. We therefore artificially removed a percentage of proteins from a collection of held-out complete genomes and computed their genome embeddings compared to the complete genomes, calculating the mean reciprocal rank (MRR). Bacformer was able to extrapolate the full genomic context even when only 50% of proteins were present, demonstrating the ability to confidently complete genomes from sparse protein sets (Fig. 5C; Fig. S13).

Since Bacformer was trained to predict protein families rather than specific proteins, we augmented its training with a contrastive loss, encouraging the model’s contextual embeddings to align closely with actual protein embeddings present in our database (see Supplementary Methods), thereby enabling retrieval of specific protein sequences from generated contextual protein embeddings (Fig. 5D). To align the protein sequence embedding with the generated contextual embeddings, we finetuned Bacformer on a non-causal protein prediction task (where 15% of proteins were masked), combining the masked objective with a contrastive loss. Resulting embeddings were significantly more similar to their true counterparts than to other proteins (Fig. S13), and demonstrated the capability to retrieve the underlying protein sequence from a contextualised protein representation (Fig. 5E).

Finally, we explored how Bacformer could be used to generate entire bacterial genomes endowed with specific properties, a core ambition of synthetic biology [80, 81, 82]. Leveraging our phenotypic trait analysis (Fig. 4), we introduced a property token at the start of each protein-family sequence (Fig. 5F), and then finetuned Bacformer to generate protein-family sequences conditional on a particular phenotype, selecting two different traits (oxygen requirement and optimal growth temperature) to evaluate its generative capacity.

We then used each phenotype-specific model to generate full genomes from an initial set of protein families drawn from held-out species, and observed functional enrichment of proteins with biological roles linked to the specified phenotype (Fig. 5G). For example: conditioning on aerobic growth produced significant positive enrichment of urate oxidase (pucL) and cytochrome c family genes (CYC), both of which catalyse key oxidative steps in purine catabolism and electron transport during aerobic respiration [83, 84], and significant depletion of proteins that promote anaerobic metabolism (such as the nitrate-responsive regulator narL and formate-hydrogen lyase component hycA [85, 86]). Conditioning on psychrophilic growth yielded significant enrichment of cold-active xylanases (xynB) and β-galactosidases (bgaB), enzymes commonly isolated from polar and deep-sea bacteria where they facilitate polysaccharide degradation at low temperature [87, 88], and significant depletion of genes (such as steroid Delta-isomerase (ksi) [89]). These findings indicate the potential utility of Bacformer for rational genome design.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Bacformer, a genomic foundation model trained on millions of diverse bacterial strains, offers a unified representation of genomes, modelled as an ordered sequence of interacting proteins, and generalises across species to incorporate the constraints and relationships that shape proteomes during evolution.

During pretraining, Bacformer generates highly informative whole-genome embeddings that identify biologically important clusters of bacteria and their associated gene content (providing important biological and/or clinical insights), and can be used to rapidly annotate unknown genomes by relating them to existing isolates with known phenotypes. Importantly Bacformer exhibits emergent properties by learning both protein-protein interactions and protein functional organisation, thereby enabling accurate prediction of operon organisation, gene essentiality, and protein function, and acquiring the syntactic rubric underpinning bacterial evolution and functional diversification, thereby driving biological discovery.

Leveraging these emergent properties, we have trained Bacformer to predict bacterial phenotypes from genomes and identify the putative causal gene modules responsible, revealing important biological processes, permitting phenotype inference within or across species at microbiome or ecological scale, and potentially enabling state prediction following perturbations.

Bacformer can also be used for generative tasks, inferring complete genomes from an incomplete set of proteins and creating a road map for de novo genome synthesis with desired properties; with clear applications to synthetic biology and bioengineering. In summary, Bacformer provides both important insights into the evolutionary language of bacterial genomic organisation and function, and a generative approach to whole genome design.

sec.title: Code and data availability
sec.p: Code and models related to this study, together with tutorials are publicly available at https://github.com/macwiatrak/Bacformer under a permissive Apache 2.0 License.

The genomic sequences and assemblies are all publicly available and downloaded from MGnify [21], SPIRE [22] and NCBI RefSeq [36]. The long-read RNA sequencing operon annotations are available at https://huggingface.co/datasets/macwiatrak/operon-identification-long-read-rna-sequencing.
Additional details on the datasets used in this study and processing are provided in Methods.

caption.title: Bacformer, a bacterial foundation model, represents bacterial genomes as a sequence of contextualised protein embeddings.
caption.p: (A) To pretrain Bacformer, we constructed a metagenome-assembled genomes (MAG) corpus, a dataset of more than 1.3 million genomes, 3 billion proteins, and 225 million contigs collected across 25,000 species and 70 distinct environments. For visualisation, the taxonomy tree represents a set of the 200 orders with the highest number of genomes in the MAG corpus, annotated by number of genomes (log; dark blue outer circle) and distribution across biospheres. (B) Bacformer model architecture and pretraining scheme. Bacformer takes as input the set of protein sequences present in a bacterial strain, ordered by genome location. Protein sequences are then embedded with a pretrained protein language model (ESM-2 [23]) and supplemented with rotary positional embeddings [24] as well as learnable contig representations. The resulting protein representations are then used as input to the transformer, which computes contextualised protein embeddings using other proteins present in the genome. During pretraining, the model predicts a protein family of the masked protein based on the genomic context. The discrete vocabulary of protein family labels necessary for pretraining were established by embedding the non-contextual protein sequences with a protein language model and performing unsupervised clustering. (C) Bacformer accurately clusters MAGs across diverse genera, in an unsupervised manner. UMAP plot showing strain clustering using Bacformer embeddings of assemblies from the 10 most frequent genera in the MAG corpus (clustering metrics: Adjusted Rand Index (ARI); Normalised Mutual Information (NMI); and Average Silhouette Width (ASW): all metrics vary from 0 to 1, higher is better; see Fig. S3 for plot legend). (D) Bacformer representation of MAGs maintains evolutionary relationships. Cosine similarity heatmap for 100 most common species of Bacteroidales showing higher similarity between species in the same family (rows) and genus (columns). (E) Bacformer reveals subpopulations within a single species. UMAP plot of Escherichia coli MAGs from the MGnify dataset [21] using genome embeddings from Bacformer annotated with Leiden clustering [25] labels (colours). (F) kNN classifier results across taxonomic ranks (family (green), genus (light blue), and species (dark blue)) demonstrate that Bacformer accurately identifies similar bacteria. Error bars represent 95% confidence interval across genomes.

caption.title: Bacformer identifies protein-protein interactions across bacterial genomes.
caption.p: (A) Bacformer can identify operons by computing the pairwise interaction scores of contiguous genes. (B) Zero-shot operon prediction performance (evaluated by area under the receiver operator characteristic (ROC) curve; AUROC) for Bacformer (blue) and ESM-2 (green, [23]) across operon sizes using a set of 45 genomes with a total of 5, 126 annotated operons obtained from Operon DB [48] as ground truth. Line and boxes represent median and interquartile range (IQR) respectively; whiskers extend 1.5 × IQR beyond Q1 and Q3; random classifier AUROC (red dashed line). (C) Bacformer zero-shot operon predictions (assessed by AUROC) for five bacterial species where we generated experimental ground truth data from long-read RNA sequencing. (D) Bacformer learns protein-protein interactions across different interaction types from STRING DB (blue) [49], outperforming non-contextual protein embeddings (ESM-2, green). The interaction scores were calculated using cosine similarity between protein representations on held-out genomes (N = 2, 088). Line and boxes represent median and interquartile range (IQR) respectively; whiskers extend 1.5 × IQR beyond Q1 and Q3; random classifier AUROC (red dashed line). (E) Finetuning Bacformer significantly boosts performance on protein-protein prediction task across genomes. We used STRING DB combined score as labels. Line and boxes represent median and interquartile range (IQR) respectively; whiskers extend 1.5 × IQR beyond Q1 and Q3. (F) ROC curves of finetuned Bacformer performance across diverse bacterial species. (G) Proteome-wide interaction scores for Pseudomons aeruginosa PAO1 predicted from finetuned Bacformer (line thickness indicates prediction strength; only predictions with probability > 0.5 were visualised). (H) Predicted structures obtained from AlphaFold3 Leiden = Bacformer [50] for top scoring protein complexes from P. aeruginosa PAO1 predicted by Bacformer (ipTM score indicates the probability of the two proteins binding together and pTM score is a measure of overall predicted structure confidence; range for both 0-1, higher is better). (I) Protein-protein interaction network extracted using clustering (resolution 40) on contextualised protein embeddings. The edge weights with high importance (cosine similarity > 0.8) are highlighted in dark blue.

caption.title: Bacformer leverages genomic context to predict gene essentiality and protein function.
caption.p: (A) Predicting gene essentiality and function using Bacformer. Top: In the zero-shot setting, we knocked-out the gene in silico by zeroing its representation at input level. We then measured the effect of the knock-out on the whole genome comparing the effect of essential and non-essential genes on genome embedding. Bottom: Bacformer is finetuned to predict protein essentiality or function label. (B) Finetuned Bacformer significantly outperforms competing methods on gene essentiality prediction across genomes on the held-out evaluation set (N = 10) evaluated by area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUROC). Line and boxes represent median and interquartile range (IQR) respectively; whiskers extend 1.5 × IQR beyond Q1 and Q3. (C) Receiver operating characteristic curves (ROC curve) for finetuned Bacformer predictions of gene essentiality across diverse species (showing AUROC values). (D) Pretrained Bacformer significantly outperforms competing methods (kNN classifier, orange; ESM-2, green; zero-shot Bacformer, light blue; finetuned Bacformer, dark blue) on protein function prediction of 503, 295 proteins across 188 functional classes. The protein function labels were taken from the MGnify dataset [21] which used KEGG [60] protein function labels (level 4). Error bars represent standard error. (E) UMAP plots of protein embeddings coloured by protein function predictions from Bacformer (left) and ESM-2 (right) for a set of 10 KEGG protein functions from the MGnify dataset. Clustering was evaluated using Average Silhouette Width (ASW; range -1 to 1; higher is better).

caption.title: Bacformer enables phenotypic traits prediction and discovery of phenotype-specific genes.
caption.p: (A) Bacformer genome embeddings capture environment niche in an unsupervised manner. Cosine similarity heatmap between strains from the Bifidobacterium genus showing higher similarity between strains from the same animal niche (chicken gut, pink; pig gut, green; human gut, blue). The dendrogram was created by performing hierarchical clustering on Bacformer genome embeddings. (B) Bacformer annotates genomes with diverse phenotypic traits. We trained phenotype-specific models using Bacformer genome embeddings as inputs to annotate genomes in the MAG corpus with more than 30 diverse phenotypic traits. (C) Phenotype prediction performance of pretrained Bacformer (dark blue), zero-shot Bacformer (light blue), and ESM-2 (green) shown for a range of phenotypes. Line and boxes represent median and interquartile range (IQR) respectively; whiskers extend 1.5 × IQR beyond Q1 and Q3. (D) Example of phenotype inference across bacterial classes. Inner circle: phylogenetic tree of a selection of bacterial genomes (sampled from the MAG corpus), colour-coded by class. Outer circles: a subset of phenotypes (from a total of 139) inferred using phenotype-specific models trained using Bacformer genome embeddings. (E) UMAP plot of the 100 genes with the highest importance scores for the sporulation phenotype across genomes (using their embeddings extracted from the last layer of the Bacformer model and averaged across genomes) and annotated by Leiden clustering label and function (function labels were established by analysing the genes within each Leiden cluster and leveraging the phenotype labels from the GIDEON dataset [62]). (F) The top 100 genes from Lactobacillus johsonii genomes with the highest importance scores for each environmental niche (human gut, brown; chicken gut, dark blue; pig gut, light blue; i.e. isolation source) and plotted as a UMAP (using gene embeddings extracted from the last layer of the Bacformer model and averaged across genomes). Some genes with known association to the environmental niche are labelled. Genomes and environmental niche labels provided by the MGnify dataset [21]. (G) UMAP plot of the top 100 protein families with highest importance scores for each environmental niche (cow rumen, green; human oral, grey; chicken gut, dark blue; human gut, brown; pig gut, light blue) across Prevotella genus genomes using protein family embeddings were extracted from the last layer of the Bacformer model and averaged across genomes. Genomes and environmental niche labels provided by the MGnify dataset [21].

caption.title: Bacformer generates whole bacterial genomes with desired properties.
caption.p: (A) Bacformer successfully generates genomes not seen during training. Next protein family prediction (orange) on Salmonella enterica (top) and P. aeruginosa (bottom) compared to true (blue) protein family distributions. (B) Bacformer generates genomes encompassing a realistic range of protein functions (predicted, orange; true, blue) for E. coli (left) and S. aureus (right). We prompted Bacformer with a short sequence of initial proteins (500) and evaluated the generated genomes against true labels. (C) Bacformer retrieves true complete genome from incomplete genomes. Mean reciprocal rank (MRR, 0-1, higher is better) of genomes generated from inputs with ablated proteins by zero-shot (light blue) and non-zero-shot finetuned Bacformer (dark blue) and ESM-2 (green). Error bars represent 95% confidence intervals. (D) Visualisation showing the process of identifying existing proteins from Bacformer generated contextual protein embeddings using next-protein family prediction. (E) Retrieval of underlying protein sequences using unmasked contextualised protein embeddings (blue) and masked (brown) embeddings across a range of k neighbours. Error bars represent standard error. (F) Bacformer generates sequences of protein families with desired properties. We finetune Bacformer to generate protein family sequences conditional on a property. The property is represented as a token appended to the beginning of the sequence. The prompt includes the property token and a set of initial protein families present in the genome which is used by the model to generate the rest of the genome. (G) We generated sequences of protein families with models finetuned for different genome properties (in this case oxygen requirement and optimal growth temperature). We then compared sequences produced with and without the property token, calculated the log2 fold change for KEGG orthology (KO) groups [60], and assessed statistical significance with Fisher’s exact test [79].
